Hi Brett,

On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@...> wrote:
>
> A=
s for option 2... We're not following agile practices. We are not pair
> pr=
ogramming. We are not doing TDD (write one test, get it to compile, get it
=
> to run, write the next test...). We are closer to a Unified Process
> men=
tality. Use cases not user stories. Design reviews, not pair programming.
>=
 Don't refactor until something is broken versus removing code smell as you=

> go along. We do have the develops and BA's working together. We do have
=
> morning stand up meetings. Some are effective, some are just quick status=

> reports (ineffective).


Sounds like a typical "real-world" software pro=
ject to me, don't feel bad if
the Agile practices don't seem very relevant =
or even practical to you.
 I ranted
about this very topic <http://beust.com=
/weblog/archives/000392.html> a few
days ago.

I check this in. Then in my =
workspace, I just change the IGNORE_UNTIL to
> something like "6/15/2005", =
whatever. One change, all the tests being
> running.


For the record, Test=
NG <http://testng.org> supports "ignores" with groups.
You would put such m=
ethods in a certain group:

@Test(groups =3D {"functional"})
public void g(=
) { ... }

@Test(groups =3D {"functional", "ignore"})
public void f() { ...=
 }

and then exclude this group from your run (e.g. "include 'functional',
=
exclude 'ignore'")

Also, the HTML reports generated by TestNG will give yo=
u a list of all the
groups and which methods belong to them, so it's very e=
asy to quickly find
out what test methods are currently being ignored.

As =
for the concept of a time bomb, it's a perfect scenario for TestNG's use
of=
 BeanShell, which lets you override TestNG's decision mechanism and lets
yo=
u write the logic that decides which methods should be included or
excluded=
 (in case groups are not good enough).

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
